61855730

61855700
>>61855681
I finished packing my bag a long time ago.
However, I regret not selling $48k worth of XRP when we were over $3 last year per XRP.
Since I have no income right now (other than savings), I could have made that sale tax free since it's long term capital gains (over a year old).
I could have kept half and created a limit buy order for half my sell price with the other half.
And we've easily gone down to $1.50 (half of $3), and then some.
$24k worth of pure tax free profit and I would have gotten back whatever XRP I sold when we dumped.
If I was wrong and it ended up never dropping to that level, it would have been fine, since that amount of XRP would have been only about 10% of my total bag.

I've bagheld XRP too long, with an all or nothing approach.
As long as your bag is big enough, taking small percentages of profits makes sense to me.

>A dollar, 1.30 or 1.50 even 2 dollars who the fuck cares.
This part doesn't apply to me, but we have anons new to crypto or XRP that still have small bags; along with poor anons that can't afford to buy much.
It's relevant to them.
Buying at different prices makes a huge difference for them if they don't have much money to buy a lot of XRP and have only a small bag.
The cheaper they can buy XRP, the bigger their bag will be.

I never dollar cost averaged my buys, when I bought in 2021 and 2022.
I saved up money from my weekly paycheck and went months, and once over a year, in between my buys.
I didn't catch any of the bottoms on my buys, but I did fair much better than if I had dollar cost averaged on each paycheck.

The 20k allowance resets every year in April. So you've got like 2 months to fill another 15k. Then your allowance is reset and you can put in another 20k for the new tax year. 61856552
>>61856539
>This could be done by going with the Judy Shelton idea: gold backed USTs..
That would make it easier to sell more debt, but the problem is, they are at over 100% of their revenue on interest and non-discretionary spending. Ie, more than 100% of their revenue is spent on costs that CANNOT be "trimmed".

Imagine I have no income and live off credit cards, getting new credit cards as I fill up my old ones, and using additional credit cards to pay the minimum payments on all the outstanding maxxed out credit cards.

Now I promise that in 50 years from now I will pay new credit cards I get back in gold.

Do you see the problem? Without reducing the debt by 70%-80% and massively cutting spendng to balance the budget, the very best that would do is add a year or two more rope to get hanged with later.

Republican politicians are so corrupt, they didn't want DOGE to seriously look at all the fraud in the US government, and especially NOT in the military, but EVEN outright scams like NED and USAID are being protected.

At least half of the left in the USA is living on patronage networks funded by US government debt.

I love Judy Shelton and think she's great, but I personally wouldn't trust the US government not to default on my "gold backed" bonds 50 years from now. What are you going to do if the US government pulls another 1971? Bomb them?

The time for threading the needle ended with 9/11 and trillions in regime changes on behalf of Israel, the most expensive parasite in the known universe.

I would be happy if facts can prove me wrong without a collapse. Financial collapse may trigger civil war and/or breakup of the USA.

>-will it be uncontrolled, ad hoc, chaotic and potentially unlimited

-an attempt at threading the needle
This could be done by going with the Judy Shelton idea: gold backed USTs..

>This is what they "show off" to visiting politicians and the media who are too stupid to know better.

61856383
>>61855985
>That only works if we still have stores of it at Fort Knox and etc
It works (and is necessary) even if the USA has zero gold.

From the POV of revaluing (devaluing) the dollar vs gold, it doesn't matter if the US has 8500 tons or not. Devaluing the dollar is needed to increase American export competiveness. Even if they still had 8500 tons of bars, it would only provide $5 trillion at best, which will soon be merely the annual deficit.

The devaluation of the dollar means the debt gets paid back via much smaller dollars. It is exactly the equivalent of a soft default, paying back 20% of the original value owed.

There is a 100% chance the US dollar will be devalued, the only question is:
-will it be a deliberate, finite, one time big jump
-will it be uncontrolled, ad hoc, chaotic and potentially unlimited

They probably still have a bunch of "coin bars" which are 90% gold that would be re-refined up to .999. This is what the "show off" to visiting politicians who are too stupid to know better.

The only reason why they would still have their coin bars is because if they tried to steal and sell them, any refiner on earth would immediate recognize these came from Fort Knox, so unlike regular fine gold, they couldn't be sold without publicly exposing the theft. The USA has probably been discreetly buying gold ever since they suddenly stopped talking about doing an audit.

As Luke Gromen says:
>All Roads Lead to Gold.

Here is an extreme scenario: AI+robotics achieve human level thinking and movement, and it is cheaper to manufacture and maintain one compared to owning a literal human slave. If such robots are privately owned, the corporations could develop an independent self sustaining economy. The corporation won't even need to think about money at this point. They won't have to think about 99% of people who don't participate in this robot economy.
More "realistic" (not really) scenario: office jobs are eliminated. Everyone is pushed into blue collar jobs, and white collar jobs that need human presence legally. Corporations save tons of money on salaries and real estate.

I wouldn't be surprised if people don't even care, or darker, say they deserved to lose their jobs and take glee and delight at seeing it happen. I already see it on social media all the time. No one is saving you. Prepare to take a low-skill physical labor job if you aren't proficient in a skilled trade, which you likely aren't. Same as most white-collar workers.

>>61855222
the pedochain and the total ruin of investors

61855946
DOT? You mean that crap I put in my cars brakes?

61855907
>>61855313
>All the parachain shit seems too autistic
It's literally just L2s on drugs. Because they have shared security with DOT. They also don't fragment liquidity like ETH L2s. They have native bridging called HRMP channels. They have literally THE BEST native decentralized governance. They can be infinitely scaled, up to more than 100k TPS and once JAM hits it'll go up to million of TPS. Very soon you'll get 500ms blocks. You can have a unified address across all the chains. You also have RISC-V architecture. DOT is literally what ETH wants to become but will take at least 10-15 years of development to come close to. Once people realize what's up it'll be too late and the price will be tripple digits.

61855808
>>61855222
Yes and my dubs confirms it

61855526
>>61855313
>Is dot used as gas for the parachains?
Yes, and also ANY OTHER parachain token can be. So on Bifrost you can use DOT, BNC, other parachain tokens and even like 4-5 different ETHs. Any token can be used as gas fee. This is natively available on DOT

>What about the bridging?
Natively built in. Also, it's not even bridging, it's called an HRMP channel and it's 100% secure.
https://docs.polkadot.com/parachains/interoperability/channels-between-parachains/
https://docs.polkadot.com/parachains/interoperability/channels-with-system-parachains/

https://polkadot.subscan.io/tools/charts?type=xcm_flow_message - You can see the flow of money here

https://hyperbridge.network/
https://app.turtle.cool/
https://app.snowbridge.network/
https://next-app.hydration.net/cross-chain
https://app.hydration.net/cross-chain


DOT is about 10 years ahead and once JAM hits it'll be about 20 years ahead. 100$ end of bull run

item.title: Thread 61856272 — 18 replies
item.content:encoded:
Thread 61856272

Open thread • Replies: 18

OP

Anons, i want to divest from the US. I see a lot of companies and people doing it. I don't want to be the last one left. I don't want to invest in crypto since a lot of countries are starting to pass regulations for it. I don't want to invest in China. Where should i put my money in? Any ideas?

Latest replies

61856568
>>61856272
Yup. US stock market is dead for the next couple weeks (plus).
Come Monday I will eject almost the last vestiges after already getting rid of MU, meaning my stupid Take Two, SOFI and MSFT plays (bought the dip -- now realize while they will eventually pay off, it's dead capital).

Getting really gooky and nippy in my 'folio.

(Also said this in the /smg/)

61856561
>>61856537
>Are those even available through Robinhood?
No idea, I have never and will never use that garbage

61856560
>>61856537
Weight of top 10 is 11,5% in EXUS.

61856537
>>61856297
Any etf that holds all those stocks with nearly equal weighting?

>>61856335
Are those even available through Robinhood?

>>61856370
Is this an even spread of all the stocks in its holdings or is it like the SPY etf where 10 companies make up nearly 40% of its holdings value?

61856370
>>61856297
EXUS is a good start.
EU Defense and finance sector broke records last year, you would be chasing those profits now.
Something to keep eye on is infra imo.

61856350
Thanks for all the good advice /biz/bros.

61856339
>>61856272
you also need to factor in exchange rates, you cannot really predict what markets are going to do the best, but what you can do is invest in the markets of countries with the weakest currencies compared to their history. That way you get to invest in markets at a discount and stack the numbers in your favor.

Some good options: Japan, Australia, Mexico, Canada

>>61856297
defence isn't a bad bet. if you're looking for single companies you should look for defence adjacent industrial businesses that are now adapting their production to defence, of which there are plenty. there is also a european defence ETF by wisdromtree, but you're buying mostly rheinmetall and saab with that one.
honestly i think that you will already outperform the S&P500 with an MSCI Europe ETF for the next couple of years, especially if the USD falls further against the EUR, so i would just go with that.
